Title: The Influence of Ai Apps on Enhancing Mathematics Learning Among Primary Education Students
Exclusion Reason: Not applicable (the paper meets the inclusion criteria).
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The influence of artificial intelligence (AI) applications on enhancing mathematics learning in primary school students..." (Abstract)
1.2 Context - Source: "These applications, along with the use of mobile devices, offer personalized tools tailored to the students' needs..." (Abstract)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "The instant feedback and interactive resources provided by AI apps contribute to more dynamic and efficient learning..." (Abstract)
1.4 Tool/Platform: Smartick, Photomath, Matific, Khan Academy, Aula 365.
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "We identified that the following applications are used in Latin America: Photomath... Smartick... Matific... Khan Academy... Aula 365..." (III. RESULT AND DISCUSSION)
1.5 Education level - Source: "The enhancement of the teaching and learning process mediated by apps in the field of education leads to the creation of new, scientifically endorsed, effective tools designed to improve the learning of our students." (I. INTRODUCTION)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "AI can also help teachers identify the individual needs of each student and design more effective teaching strategies." (IV. CONCLUSIONS)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through AI applications that allow for personalized learning experiences and support in areas where students need it.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "This allows students to learn at their own pace and receive additional support in areas where they need it." (IV. CONCLUSIONS)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided by AI applications is immediate and tailored to individual student needs, enhancing their learning experience.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "The implementation of AI tools in mathematics teaching has a positive impact on student performance and understanding..." (III. RESULT AND DISCUSSION)
3.1 Agency type: Student agency through self-directed learning.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "It is understood that the advancement of new technologies has evolved rapidly, causing most people to feel lost with these tools, as they have facilitated work in various contexts." (III. RESULT AND DISCUSSION)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students have control over when they receive feedback through the use of AI applications.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "This allows students to learn at their own pace..." (IV. CONCLUSIONS)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Academic performance and understanding of mathematical concepts.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "The results indicate that the implementation of AI tools in mathematics teaching has a positive impact on student performance and understanding..." (III. RESULT AND DISCUSSION)

Title: Effectiveness and Guidance of Artificial Intelligence Chatbots in Diagnosing Exponential Expression Errors
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The study reveals that chatbots may encounter difficulties in detecting and correcting conceptual misunderstandings... the study recommends the integration of synchronous and asynchronous classroom environments in which teachers can closely monitor student responses." (Introduction, p. 548)
1.2 Context - Source: "This study aims to examine students’ learning errors related to exponential expressions and to explore the underlying causes of these errors." (Purpose and contribution of the study, p. 552)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "The primary rationale for selecting ChatGPT and Gemini in this study lies in the fact that both models are current, powerful, widely accessible, and possess distinct technical capabilities." (Purpose and contribution of the study, p. 552)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "The study investigates the potential of generative AI-based chatbots—namely ChatGPT and Gemini—to identify students’ misconceptions regarding exponential expressions..." (Purpose and contribution of the study, p. 552)
1.5 Education level - Source: "The items in the administered test cover learning outcomes related to exponential expressions in the 8th-grade mathematics curriculum." (Data collection tool, p. 553)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "The findings indicate that both ChatGPT-4 and Gemini were partially successful in identifying and correcting students’ misconceptions." (Abstract, p. 547)
2.2 Description of context: Chatbots analyze student responses and provide feedback based on misconceptions identified in their answers.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "Students were asked to share their solutions for each question with AI-supported chatbots and to proceed based on the feedback they received from the bots." (Data collection and analysis, p. 553)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided by the chatbots is sometimes effective but can also be misleading, indicating a need for careful monitoring by teachers.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "While ChatGPT-4 demonstrated the ability to accurately classify student responses and provide effective guidance in many cases, it was also observed to occasionally misclassify answers and provide incorrect guidance." (Findings regarding the guidance provided by ChatGPT-4, p. 558)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; students interact with chatbots for feedback but do not fully control the feedback process.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "The study seeks to assess whether students, without direct teacher support, can recognize and potentially correct their misconceptions with the help of chatbots in informal learning settings." (Purpose and contribution of the study, p. 552)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control the timing of feedback; it is provided after they submit their answers.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Students were asked to share their solutions for each question with AI-supported chatbots and to proceed based on the feedback they received from the bots." (Data collection and analysis, p. 553)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Classification of student responses into categories such as correct knowledge, lack of confidence, lack of knowledge, and misconception.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "The classification criteria for student responses were developed by considering the potential types of responses students might give." (Data collection and analysis, p. 553)

Title: Large Scale Assessments for Learning a Human Centred Ai Approach to Contextualizing Test Performance
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "educators need to know what students know and can do, so that they can be prepared for education policies and interventions in teaching and learning." (Introduction, p. 229)
1.2 Context - Source: "Large-scale assessments play a key role in education" (Introduction, p. 229)
1.3 Tech/AI type: Human-centred AI (HAI) framework utilizing machine learning techniques.
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "we leveraged machine learning techniques (including supervised, unsupervised, and active learning) and experimented with a general human-centred AI approach" (Introduction, p. 229)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "the released National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP) Grade 8 mathematics data were used to illustrate our proposed approach." (Introduction, p. 229)
1.5 Education level - Source: "the 2017 NAEP Grade 8 mathematics assessment" (Data, p. 230)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "the resulting process profiles could provide rich feedback to educators and policymakers for teaching and learning." (Notes for Practice, p. 229)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is generated from process data that reflects students' test-taking processes and performance.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "Process data, combined with response data, reflect students’ test-taking processes and can provide educators such rich information" (Introduction, p. 229)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is contextualized and aims to enhance understanding of student performance beyond mere scores.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "the current study proposes a general and systematic human-centred AI (HAI) framework for critical decision making, to analyze complex and large data at scale" (Notes for Practice, p. 229)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; feedback is primarily directed towards educators and policymakers.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "provide educators with actionable feedback that nurtures the broader skills students need to succeed and thrive" (HAI Framework, p. 232)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Not specified.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Not specified" (Not applicable)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Performance scores and process data metrics such as response times and tool usage.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "the maximum item score varies from 1 point to 4 points" (Data, p. 230)

Title: “exceptional Talent and Enthusiasm for Math” an Examination of Storylines Circulated by Chatgpt About Mathematical Learners
Exclusion Reason: Not applicable (the paper meets the inclusion criteria).
1.1 Primary Stakeholders: Students, specifically those identified as gifted, special education, English language learners, and from various racial/ethnic backgrounds.
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "Learners included academic labels, like gifted and special education, and race/ethnicity, like Black or Asian." (Introduction, p. 1620)
1.2 Context: The context is an exploratory study examining feedback provided by ChatGPT on mathematical writing.
1.2 Context - Source: "To understand how AI chatbots participate in such storylines, we examined ChatGPT’s feedback to different learners’ mathematical writing in an exploratory study." (Abstract, p. 1620)
1.3 Tech/AI type: AI chatbot, specifically ChatGPT developed by OpenAI.
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "ChatGPT, an artificial intelligent (AI) chatbot developed by Open AI." (Introduction, p. 1620)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "We focused our attention on ChatGPT because it is one of the most popular (Larsen, 2023; Ortiz, 2023), free to users, and does not have restrictions." (Methods, p. 1623)
1.5 Education level - Source: "Write feedback to the fifth grade student who answered the garage problem." (Methods, p. 1623)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "ChatGPT’s feedback included praise for clarity and organization." (Findings, p. 1627)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided in a structured format, including greeting, praise, discussion of content, and closing remarks.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "The feedback included: 1) greeting, 2) opening praise, 3) discussed mathematical content (2-3 paragraphs), 4) worked-out solution (if it identified the answer as wrong), 5) closing praise (1-2 paragraphs), 6) offer of ongoing support, and 7) signature." (Methods, p. 1624)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided by ChatGPT often aligns with existing narratives about learners, sometimes reinforcing stereotypes.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "While it is unlikely that a practicing teacher would elicit feedback from ChatGPT... it is important for educators... to understand the extent that emergent AI tools have learned to participate in broader storylines about mathematical learners." (Discussion, p. 1631)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; feedback is primarily controlled by the AI's responses.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "ChatGPT does not appear to have rewritten, per se, feedback to each new student, but to have modified its previous feedback." (Limitations and Future Research, p. 1632)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control the timing of feedback; it is provided after their responses are submitted.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "ChatGPT was asked to give feedback from this role to the following learner’s response to the mathematics problem." (Methods, p. 1623)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: The study evaluates the quality of feedback based on its alignment with educational narratives and the effectiveness of the feedback structure.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "We used positioning theory as our conceptual framework... to analyze the data." (Methods, p. 1625)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is not explicitly measured; the focus is on the feedback provided and its implications for student positioning.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "Future work should attend to the interaction between various learner characteristics as it appears (or doesn’t) in the responses of large language models." (Limitations and Future Research, p. 1633)

Title: Real Time Ai Driven Assessment and Scaffolding That Improves Students’ Mathematical Modeling During Science Investigations
Exclusion Reason: Not applicable (the paper meets all inclusion criteria).
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "Participants included 70 students across four eighth grade science classes taught by the same teacher from the same school..." (Section 2.1, page 204).
1.2 Context - Source: "Students completed two Inq-ITS mathematical modeling virtual labs during their regularly scheduled classes." (Section 2.1, page 204).
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "We present the design and initial classroom test of AI-scaffolded virtual labs that help students practice these competencies." (Abstract, page 202).
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "In this paper, we evaluate the design of virtual labs in the Inquiry Intelligent Tutoring System (Inq-ITS)..." (Section 1, page 203).
1.5 Education level - Source: "Participants included 70 students across four eighth grade science classes..." (Section 2.1, page 204).
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "The automated scaffolding appears as an on-screen pop-up message delivered from a pedagogical agent, Rex." (Section 2.3, page 208).
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided in real-time based on students' performance in the virtual labs.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "If the student completes the task correctly (i.e., receives 1 for all sub-practices), they can proceed to the next stage. If not, individualized scaffolding is automatically triggered..." (Section 2.3, page 208).
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is targeted and specific to the sub-practices where students struggle, enhancing their learning experience.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "This proactive approach was chosen because students often cannot recognize when to ask for help..." (Section 2.3, page 208).
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency in feedback timing; feedback is provided based on performance.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "Students are prevented from moving forward to the next stage if they do not complete the task correctly." (Section 2.3, page 208).
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control feedback timing; it is triggered by their performance.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Individualized scaffolding is automatically triggered based on the sub-practices on which the student was correct or incorrect..." (Section 2.3, page 208).
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Average of sub-practice scores for each stage.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "To measure students’ competencies, students’ stage scores are calculated as the average of the sub-practice scores for that stage..." (Section 2.4, page 210).

Title: Constraint Based Student Modelling in Probability Story Problems with Scaffolding Techniques
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The subjects of the test were students enrolled in the third secondary level in the Egyptian educational system." (Section 8.1, page 196)
1.2 Context: Classroom setting, specifically for probability story problems.
1.2 Context - Source: "MAST is a Web-based intelligent tutoring system for probability story problems." (Section 4, page 182)
1.3 Tech/AI type: Intelligent Tutoring System (ITS) utilizing Constraint-Based Modeling (CBM).
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "Constraint-Based student Modeling (CBM) is an important technique employed in intelligent tutoring systems to model student knowledge to provide relevant assistance." (Abstract, page 178)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "This paper introduces the Math Story Problem Tutor (MAST), a Web-based intelligent tutoring system for probability story problems." (Section 1, page 179)
1.5 Education level - Source: "The subjects of the test were students enrolled in the third secondary level in the Egyptian educational system." (Section 8.1, page 196)
2.1 Feedback term: Scaffolding feedback, hints, and keywords highlighting.
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "MAST exploits both scaffolding questions and scaffolding feedback." (Section 7, page 194)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through highlighting keywords and scaffolding questions to guide students in solving probability problems.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "MAST provides different levels of feedback. It starts by presenting a clue to the student by highlighting the related violated constraint keywords that may be misinterpreted by the student." (Section 7.2, page 195)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is specific and targeted, allowing students to understand their errors and correct them effectively.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "The highlighted keywords, and the general feedback, are provided automatically to the student upon submission of an answer." (Section 7.2, page 195)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency, as the system provides structured feedback and guidance.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "The student is also allowed to check the event set elements and in case of an error, the student may request help about what is wrong with the answer." (Section 7.2, page 195)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control the timing of feedback; it is provided after answer submission.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "The highlighted keywords, and the general feedback, are provided automatically to the student upon submission of an answer." (Section 7.2, page 195)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Paired samples t-test, normalized knowledge gain, and Mann-Whitney U test.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "The goal of the evaluation is to assess the effectiveness of MAST in tutoring the students using various tests." (Section 8, page 196)

Title: Analyzing Students’ Performance in Computerized Formative Assessments to Optimize Teachers’ Test Administration Decisions Using Deep Learning Frameworks
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "the proposed system would greatly help teachers make more systematic and informed test administration decisions and thereby maximize the effectiveness of computerized formative assessments in promoting student learning." (Introduction, p. 72)
1.2 Context: Classroom setting with computerized formative assessments.
1.2 Context - Source: "computerized formative assessments refer to assessment methods that use computers to support the management and delivery of classroom assessment." (Literature review, p. 73)
1.3 Tech/AI type: Deep learning frameworks, specifically Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks.
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "we introduced a prediction model for a computerized formative assessment system to detect the optimal number of tests for each student." (The current study, p. 76)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "The dataset used in the study was collected from Star Math—a well-known formative assessment used for screening and progress monitoring purposes." (Methods, p. 78)
1.5 Education level - Source: "Our dataset included performance scores of 10,107 students in grade 1." (Methods, p. 78)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "Not specified" (No specific feedback terms were mentioned in the paper.)
2.2 Description of context: The feedback mechanism involves predicting the number of test administrations based on students' performance data.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "the purpose of the current study was to introduce a systematic and automatic framework that could detect the students’ learning progress to determine whether more test administrations are required in math formative assessments." (Discussion and conclusion, p. 89)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is predictive in nature, aimed at optimizing test administration rather than traditional feedback mechanisms.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "Our results indicated that with performance history based on only three consecutive assessments, we could predict whether further test participation is meaningful with very high accuracy." (Discussion and conclusion, p. 89)
3.1 Agency type: Teacher agency in decision-making regarding test administration.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "the task of identifying an optimum number of tests to administer for each student has been considered a daunting, oftentimes, unattainable process." (Discussion and conclusion, p. 89)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Not specified.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Not specified" (The paper does not mention if students control the timing of feedback.)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "we used commonly employed classification accuracy metrics, such as the average accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score." (Methods, p. 80)
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "Not specified" (The paper does not provide a specific measurement for agency.)

Title: Development of a Generative Ai Powered Teachable Agent for Middle School Mathematics Learning a Design Based Research Study
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The three empirical studies involved a total of 320 middle school students and six teachers in authentic classroom settings." (Introduction, p. 2043)
1.2 Context: Authentic classroom settings for mathematics learning.
1.2 Context - Source: "This study chronicles one usability testing and three cycles of iterative design and implementation process of ALTER-M ath." (Introduction, p. 2043)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "This study designed and developed a generative AI-powered teachable agent to support secondary school students' mathematics learning." (Introduction, p. 2044)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "We name the generative AI-powered teachable agent for mathematics learning ALTER-M ath." (Introduction, p. 2044)
1.5 Education level - Source: "The three empirical studies involved a total of 320 middle school students..." (Introduction, p. 2043)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "This feedback can take various forms, such as quizzes, simulations or real-world tasks that the agent attempts to complete based on the instruction it has received." (Teachable agent, p. 2046)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided as students teach the agent, reflecting their understanding and effectiveness.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "As students teach the agent, the system provides feedback on the agent's performance, which indirectly reflects the student's teaching effectiveness and understanding of the subject matter." (Teachable agent, p. 2046)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback mechanism aligns with the learning-by-teaching approach, enhancing understanding through teaching.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "This promotes self-regulated learning by involving students in the active teaching of the agent, naturally leading them to organise, monitor and evaluate their own learning progress." (Teachable agent, p. 2046)
3.1 Agency type: Student agency through teaching the AI agent.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "Learning by teaching is realised in different formats, such as peer tutoring, where students engage in one-on-one or one-on-multiple tutoring sessions to teach younger or less knowledgeable peers." (Theoretical framework, p. 2048)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students control the timing of feedback through their interactions with the agent.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Students' teachable agent would gain different points based on their selected difficulty level and types of interaction." (Design and development of ALTER-Math, p. 2052)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Pre- and post-knowledge tests, usability surveys, and qualitative feedback.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "The final study included pre- and post- knowledge tests in a quasi-experimental study design as well as student and teacher interviews." (Introduction, p. 2044)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through students' ability to teach the agent and their reflections on the teaching process.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "This allows students to practice in authentic contexts and receive timely, relevant explanations." (Teachable agent, p. 2046)

Title: Improving the Validity of Automatically Generated Feedback via Reinforcement Learning
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "We experiment on a dataset that consists of feedback messages written by math teachers for each incorrect option in multiple-choice questions." (Section 1, page 281)
1.2 Context: Online learning platforms and intelligent tutoring systems.
1.2 Context - Source: "Automatically generating feedback via large language models (LLMs) in intelligent tutoring systems and online learning platforms has the potential to improve the learning outcomes of many students." (Section 1, page 280)
1.3 Tech/AI type: Large language models (LLMs) and reinforcement learning (RL).
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "We propose a framework for feedback generation that optimizes both correctness and alignment using reinforcement learning (RL)." (Section 1, page 280)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "We primarily use the instruction-tuned Llama-2 7B Chat model... We show that GPT-4 can evaluate feedback rather accurately using a rubric." (Section 5, page 292)
1.5 Education level - Source: "We validate our framework using a dataset of middle school-level math multiple choice questions from Eedi." (Section 4.1, page 286)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "The feedback correctly points out the error the student made or the misconception underlying their answer." (Section 3.1, page 283)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is generated for incorrect student responses to math questions, focusing on correctness and pedagogical alignment.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "We propose a framework that both generates and evaluates feedback messages for incorrect student responses to questions, to improve both their correctness and alignment with educational goals." (Section 1, page 280)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback generated is aimed at being pedagogically valid and aligned with educational goals, focusing on understanding student errors.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "Feedback also has to be pedagogically valid to reflect effective tutoring strategies, such as explaining possible misconceptions and encouraging the student." (Section 1, page 280)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; feedback is primarily automated.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "However, doing so is challenging since generated feedback should satisfy a wide variety of requirements." (Section 1, page 280)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Not specified.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Not specified." (Not explicitly mentioned in the paper)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Rubric scores, accuracy, precision, recall, F1 scores, ROUGE-L, and BERTScore.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "We report the average of each rubric label in y and the corresponding scores s assigned by GPT-4." (Section 4.2, page 287)
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "Not specified." (Not explicitly mentioned in the paper)

Title: Stimulating Individual Learning of the Concept of Fraction Equivalence
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "Participants were 300 sixth-grade students from secondary schools in Germany." (Method, page 5)
1.2 Context: Classroom setting during a mathematics lesson focused on fractions.
1.2 Context - Source: "The study was conducted at the beginning of the school year 2022/2023." (Method, page 5)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "The experimental group used an adaptive digital learning environment for practice." (Method, page 5)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "Not specified." (Not explicitly mentioned in the paper)
1.5 Education level - Source: "Participants were 300 sixth-grade students from secondary schools in Germany." (Method, page 5)
2.1 Feedback term: Individualized feedback, explanatory feedback, corrective feedback.
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "Immediate individualized feedback and adaptive adjustment of task difficulty can provide cognitive relief and prevent cognitive overload." (Introduction, page 2)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided based on students' performance in real-time, adjusting task difficulty and offering explanations for errors.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "The feedback is based on scientific recommendations... which include a combination of positive reinforcement and explanatory feedback." (Method, page 6)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is both corrective and explanatory, aimed at enhancing understanding and reducing cognitive load.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "Explanatory feedback... is designed to provide both correctness verification and targeted guidance to support conceptual understanding." (Method, page 6)
3.1 Agency type: Student agency is present as students can control their learning pace and task selection.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "Students perceive themselves as competent in their ability to cope with the demands of their environment." (Introduction, page 2)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students have some control over when they receive feedback based on their interactions with the tasks.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "The digital learning environment offers three tasks... the difficulty of the printed exercises increased in a linear fashion through ascending levels." (Method, page 6)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Performance scores on fraction tasks, perceived competence, autonomy support, and perceived overload.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "We expected a correlation between perceived competence support, perceived autonomy support, and perceived demand." (Method, page 5)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through students' self-reported perceptions of competence and autonomy during the learning process.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "The satisfaction of the fundamental psychological needs for competence and autonomy represents a pivotal factor in the enhancement of motivational-emotional engagement." (Introduction, page 2)

Title: Enhancing Formative Assessment in Statistics Through Classroom Action Research
1.1 Primary Stakeholders: Students and instructors in a higher education statistics class.
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "This study is rooted in my multi-disciplinary three-unit statistics class at a private higher education institution in the Philippines." (Context of the study, page 382)
1.2 Context: Higher education statistics class during the COVID-19 pandemic.
1.2 Context - Source: "Due to state-implemented pandemic guidelines, the institution shifted to flexible learning modalities, where online learning is the most prominent method used." (Context of the study, page 382)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "One of the web-based technologies is the Learning Management System (LMS), which is intended to improve education delivery by assisting instructors in managing activities online." (Introduction, page 382)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "We opted for adopting MyOpenMath as our platform primarily because it has all the functions we needed." (Methods and action plan, page 386)
1.5 Education level - Source: "This study is rooted in my multi-disciplinary three-unit statistics class at a private higher education institution in the Philippines." (Context of the study, page 382)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "We deemed it necessary to incorporate immediate feedback per item in the formative assessment we were designing." (Action implementation: formative assessment development, page 388)
2.2 Description of context: Formative assessments were administered asynchronously through the LMS, allowing students to practice statistical exercises at their convenience.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "Due to the limitations, I opted to deliver formal formative assessments that would allow students to practice statistical exercises asynchronously through the university’s LMS." (Context of the study, page 383)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided was immediate and aimed to correct misconceptions, which aligns with the purpose of formative assessment.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "The immediate feedback from the system motivated them to identify their mistakes and strive to get the correct answer." (Concluding remarks, page 392)
3.1 Agency type: Student agency in managing their learning through asynchronous assessments and multiple attempts.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "Students also expressed that they appreciate that they can partially answer the activity, take a break, and return to where they left off." (Results and discussion, page 390)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Yes, students control the timing of feedback as they can attempt assessments multiple times.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "We structured the formative assessment items to allow students 100 tries (the limit of MyOpenMath) to reattempt problems they missed." (Action implementation: formative assessment development, page 388)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Student reflections, average number of attempts, and time spent on assessments.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "We note the average number of attempts and average time students spent per attempt in the formative assessments through the data analytics of MyOpenMath." (Results and discussion, page 390)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through student reflections on their learning experiences and their ability to manage their assessment attempts.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "A student mentioned that this is a great improvement because the provision to complete the assessment fragmentally aided them in ‘managing their time’ and ‘having enough time to study again for the items they missed’." (Results and discussion, page 390)

1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "The AI-generated hints are offered in all the online homework assignments on kudu.com." (Section I, Introduction)
1.5 Education level - Source: "These interventions... are therefore very promising for creating more equitable undergraduate quantitative courses." (Section I, Introduction)

2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided by AI-generated hints is supportive and aims to enhance problem-solving skills without directly solving the problems for students.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "They are meant to guide students in the problem-solving process instead of completely giving away the answer." (Appendix B)

Title: “i Didn’t Understand, I´m Really Not Very Smart”—how Design of a Digital Tutee’s Self Efficacy Affects Conversation and Student Behavior in a Digital Math Game
Exclusion Reason: Not applicable (the paper meets the inclusion criteria).
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "we explore the effects of designing a pedagogical agent’s self-efficacy in order to see what effects this has on students’ interaction with it." (Introduction, page 1)
1.2 Context: The context is a digital math game where students interact with a digital tutee.
1.2 Context - Source: "We have analyzed chat logs from an educational math game incorporating an agent, which acts as a digital tutee." (Abstract, page 1)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "the type of pedagogical agent used in the study presented in this paper is a teachable conversational agent." (1.1. Conversational Teachable Agents, page 3)
1.4 Tool/Platform: The Squares Family (the name of the math game).
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "The math game 'The Squares Family' trains basic arithmetic skills related to the base-ten concept." (2.1. The Math Game, page 5)
1.5 Education level - Source: "In total, 166 fourth graders (83 girls and 83 boys) participated in the data collection." (2.3. Participants, page 10)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "This type of feedback is what [29] call recursive feedback, namely feedback that occurs when the tutor observes her students use what she has taught them." (1.1. Conversational Teachable Agents, page 3)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through chat after game sessions, reflecting the digital tutee's self-efficacy.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "The chat always started with a feedback-sentence that expressed the digital tutee’s self-efficacy (high or low)." (2.1.1. The Chat, page 6)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback mechanism is designed to encourage students by reflecting the tutee's self-efficacy, which influences student engagement and responses.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "students responded more frequently to feedback from a digital tutee with low self-efficacy, and these responses were mostly positive." (3.1. Responses to Feedback, page 13)
3.1 Agency type: Student agency is present as students can control the interaction with the digital tutee.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "the student can teach Lo in two different modes." (2.1. The Math Game, page 5)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control the timing of feedback; it is provided after game sessions.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "The chat appeared after every finished game." (2.1.1. The Chat, page 6)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Frequency of responses to feedback and performance on multiple-choice questions.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "To measure the students’ responses to the feedback provided by the tutee we used the code 'Answer To Feedback' (AFB)." (2.5.1. Chat Measures, page 11)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through the students' interactions and comments during the chat.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "the comments regarding the digital tutee’s intelligence or competence were noted." (3.2. Comments on the Tutee’s Intelligence and Competence, page 14)

Title: Using Large Language Models to Diagnose Math Problem Solving Skills at Scale

1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "We propose a large language model (LLM) pipeline that diagnoses students’ problem-solving skills from their answers at scale in elementary school math word problems." (Introduction, page 471)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "We developed a problem-solving framework and an LLM pipeline to scaffold and diagnose four primary skills in mathematical problem-solving." (Framework Development, page 472)
1.5 Education level - Source: "We evaluated our pipeline’s diagnosis accuracy against vanilla GPT-3.5 and vanilla GPT-4 with automatic and expert evaluations." (Introduction, page 471)

2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is tailored and aims to improve students' understanding and skills in problem-solving.

4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Accuracy of diagnosis and expert evaluations.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "We conducted technical and expert evaluations using vanilla GPT-3.5 and GPT-4 models as baselines." (4.2 Technical Evaluation, page 473)
